repnme.cdata!:
India - Agricultural Development Project -
            Tamil Nadu

abstracts.cdata!:
This project's outcome is assessed
            as satisfactory. Project sustainability is assessed as
            likely. Both World Bank and Borrower performances are rated
            satisfactory overall. General lessons learned from this
            project include the following: Studies to prepare a
            perspective plan for development, reviews of public
            expenditure, and mandate and manpower policies of the
            concerned agencies were critical for designing meaningful
            policy interventions and institutional development. These
            studies should always precede project information. The
            legislation required to make operational the institutional
            arrangements for the sharing of costs and benefits of
            community forest management was absent. As a result, the
            implementation of joint forest management within the project
            was not possible, despite important attitudinal shifts in
            favor of community involvement in forestry activities.
            Disseminating information on commercial trade in pesticides
            removed the conflict of interest between the sale of
            pesticides and the promotion of biological control.
            Involving the beneficiaries-particularly women-as caretakers
            in operation and maintenance of the rural drinking water
            supply ensured this component's sustainability.
            Identifying monitoring indicators and undertaking baseline
            surveys was crucial to obtaining meaningful interpretation
            of project implementation progress.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Agricultural Development Project -
            Tamil Nadu

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to: (a)
            improve the capability of the Government of Tamil Nadu to
            analyze development constraints and establish priorities;
            (b) further develop the institutions for rendering more
            cost-effective service to farmers; and (c) support selected
            priority state investment programs in agricultural and rural
            development identified in the state agricultural perspective
            plan.  To achieve these objectives, the project will
            comprise the following components: (a) agricultural
            planning; (b) agricultural extension; (c) seed production;
            (d) integrated watershed development; (e) livestock
            development; (f) forestry development; (g) rural road
            infrastructure; (h) rural water supply.
